urn:contentItem:5W46-K6K1-DY0W-43T2-00000-00Trump Says Summit with North Korea's Kim Jong-un May Be Delayed; North Korea Allows South Korea Reporters to Visit Nuclear Site, Official Says; Crisis In Venezuela; White House Speaker Paul Ryan Facing New Pressure To Step Down; Amazon Is Selling Facial Recognition Technology To Law Enforcement2018-05-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:59ZLexisNexisTrump Says Summit with North Korea's Kim Jong-un May Be Delayed; North Korea Allows South Korea Reporters to Visit Nuclear Site, Official Says; Crisis In Venezuela; White House Speaker Paul Ryan Facing New Pressure To Step Down; Amazon Is Selling Facial Recognition Technology To Law EnforcementLanhamFULL TEXT

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good night from New York.

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: All right. Let's take a live look and listen to President Trump. He's speaking at the Susan B. Anthony List 11th Annual Campaign for Life Gala at the National Building Museum in Washington, D.C. Let's go.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I watch him all the time. I don't know him well, but I'll get to know him. John Rutherford, where is he, John? Central casting. Great job, John. He's always defending me. Actually, most of you are always defending me and that's OK. And from my neck of the woods, Claudia Kenny. Thank you, Claudia. Thank you. And for those many that I have left out, I'm sorry. But I say, give me a totally complete list and I will call you tomorrow and I will apologize personally. All right. But every day between now and November, we must work together to elect more lawmakers who share our values, cherish our heritage, and proudly stand for life. And that is a great group of people I introduced. I can tell you that. We're also glad to be joined by a beloved member of my administration, a true fighter for faith and family, and your 2018 distinguished leader, Kellyanne Conway. Kellyanne. What a job --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Sorry. The president of course speaking introduction luminaries there at the gala and we will dip back in if there is some breaking news or he stumbles upon something that you need to hear about it because you got it right here, baby. There have been some major twists in President Trump's scheduled meeting with Kim Jong-un. The president saying he no longer likes the North Korean dictator's attitude and casting doubt that the meeting will happen at all. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If it doesn't happen, maybe it will happen later. Maybe it will happen at a different time. But we will see. But we are talking. The meeting is scheduled as you know on June 12th in Singapore. And whether or not it happens, you'll be knowing pretty soon, but we're talking right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Talking may not be good enough. We're being told Kim Jong-un may have second thoughts about giving up all of his nuclear weapons. The president today said the dictator would be making a huge mistake by walking away from this all-important table. And just yesterday, Vice President Pence told our own Martha MacCallum that if he keeps his nukes, the situation could end really, really badly. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It would be a great mistake for Kim Jong-un to think he could play Donald Trump. The truth is that President Trump has made it clear that this administration will not tolerate the regime in North Korea possessing nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles that threaten our people, that threaten the United States of America , that threaten our allies in the region.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: The vice president went on to say that North Korea will end up like Libya if it doesn't make a deal. And we all remember how that ended. The country was destroyed. Muammar Gaddafi was murdered in the street by rebels. Wow. So will Kim Jong-un play ball or is the meeting and the possible Nobel Prize out the window? With me now Fox Business Reporter Edward Lawrence with all the details. Edward.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well, Kennedy, this is the first time that we're hearing the president actually say that the meeting may not go forward on June 12th. However, the State Department is saying that they are working towards that date and only that date.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF STATE: I do have a real sense that he would -- he would find American investment, American technology, American know how of real value to his people. If we get this right and we get the denuclearization right, America wouldn't be quite capable of delivering them with lots of things that would make life better for the North Korean people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And President Trump saying that he personally guarantees the safety of Kim Jong-un at the meeting in Singapore. He president going on to say that he recognizes that fact that Kim Jong-un would be the person to lead his people into the future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I would say that we are looking certainly right now at two Koreas, two very successful Koreas. You're going to have a very, very successful North Korea and you're going to have a very successful and you already do, South Korea.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now, all of this is predicated on denuclearization. And right now, there's a group of journalists from the United States, from China, Russia, and the United Kingdom that are expected to witness the North Koreans actually taking down, demolishing one of their nuclear sites. Now, whether in the area has delayed that trip. It is expected to happen again today or tomorrow their time, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: Yes, same thing. Edward, thank you so much. All right. So Kim -- can Kim Jong-un be trusted to keep his word? And is China throwing a monkey wrench into the work? That question answers itself. It certainly is fuzz bud. Just let me bring in former CIA operative Mike Baker, also the President of Diligence LLC. Welcome back to the show, Mike.

MIKE BAKER, PRESIDENT, DILIGENCE LLC: Thank you very much, Kennedy. Thank you.

MONTGOMERY: Absolutely. The president says that Kim Jong-un's attitude needs an adjustment since his most of recent chat with President Xi Jinping. What do you think about China's meddling in a situation they're not necessarily a part of?

BAKER: Well, in that you just -- that last part of your sentence is important to note. What China wants to insure is that they're relevant in these conversations. And they made that fairly clear over the past couple of months. But, look, nobody is surprised by sort of the posturing that's taking place on both sides leading into this. This is an historic potentially defining moment. Even if the summit occurs and nothing happens after that and we can't get through the lengthy negotiations to get some type of deal signed, just getting to this point almost being at the table is an historic moment given how many years we've spent kicking the can down the road with a fairly feckless foreign policy towards North Korea. So I think that the administration has been pretty clear in stating that they understand this could be problematic and saying they're going to walk away from the table. It is interesting to note that aside from the fact you can't swing a dead cat without hitting a North Korea expert these days. It's also interesting to know that you got members of the resistance and some members of the media who seemed almost hoping for this thing to fall apart. And if you find yourself rooting against peace on the peninsula because you don't like President Trump, then you might want to rethink your priorities.

MONTGOMERY: I absolutely agree with you about that. And I think there is a time and a place for resistance. I think there are certainly instances where you have to hold the president accountable for the things the he says and does. But here I think, you know, this is an area where we have to be as supportive as possible because a peaceful ending to this situation is critical. It's paramount. Now, what's interesting and something that you have pointed out is obviously there are issues with the Iran deal. And you have noted that part of the issue is because President Obama was so impatient, and he was so dead set on landing that deal that he really compromise our position there. So would you caution this president against doing the same thing with North Korea?

BAKER: Right. And, again, they've been very been clear in saying over the past many weeks that they'd be willing to get up from the table and walk away. But what they have to be careful about is as you get closer and closer to that potential meeting on the 12th of June, you have to be careful that you feel so invested in this now, and you -- you're so keen to get this going. But you have to step back, take a breath, and understand that, as you said, the previous administration, the Obama administration, you know, they had their knickers in such a twist over the desire to get a deal, any deal, that they were willing to overlook the problems with the deal and they were willing to accept all the requests and concessions and demands that the Iranian regime put into that deal. And so, you know, and again, with anything that takes place in this world of weapons agreements whether you're talking about conventional weapons, nuclear weapons, biological or chemical weapons really at the end of the day what matters more than anything else is verification.

Trust but verify. If you can't verify and the Iranian example is a good one because it was in the deal. We were not allowed to inspect military sites. So, yes, were they complying as people who were supporting that the deal say? Well, they were complying with it. Yes, we got -- they were complying with what was written in the deal. But we had no verification capability for any of their military sites. And frankly, that's like saying you're a serial killer. You allow the police to come into your home and search it, but you can't go in the basement and look around. So we get to be really careful and if we do get to that hard difficult point where we're actually trying to pen a deal. If we can't get verification locked down with this, we didn't have it with the Syrian chemical issue. We didn't have it in the past on occasion with the Russians --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: -- trust Russia because they said they got rid of all Syria's chemical weapons. And he also said that we're fine in Iran because he read the deal, and it's super solid, and they have no desire to manufacture any fissile material or use those in drills to make big --

(CROSSTALK)

BAKER: That was their investment. They were so -- they were so keen as you pointed out. So keen to get that deal, so we have to be careful. The Trump administration has to be able to say, no, we're not going to sit down if what appears to be as the North Koreas are making demands and concessions that we can't accept, don't even sit at the table, and much less walk away. Just don't sit down at that point. Everybody understands this is an incredibly complex issue between us, North Korea, South Korea, China, Japan, you know, but this is -- again, it's worth pursuing and as you pointed out, everybody regardless of your political position should be willing to root for peace on the peninsula or an effort to get there.

MONTGOMERY: Pretend the U.S. is actually in the World Cup, it's like that. Everyone wants team USA to win. Mike Baker, thank you so much.

BAKER: What -- the World Cup is what? That's soccer?

MONTGOMERY: All right. That's enough. All right. Dear, come on. Let it go. Come on, man. It's a beautiful game and you're a lovely person, so thanks again. Today, former President Jimmy -- oh, Jimmy Carter said he thinks the president would deserve the Nobel Prize if he manages -- that's a big if. He's really qualifying this. To get the North Koreans to give up their nukes, but is the President Trump really thinking about canceling the meeting or is possible that he's just being a showman and amping up the drama? Let me go to my military grade party pane tonight, she's an editor at Townhall.com and a Fox News Contributor, Katie Pavlich is here. He is a spokesperson at Young Voices and host of the podcast Beltway Banthas, it's Stephen Kent, and he is the host of "YOUR WELCOME", that's a podcast and author of the book, Dear Reader: The Unauthorized Autobiography of Kim Jong-il, he's got a license too, Michael Malice is back. Our resident actual North Korea expert.

MICHAEL MALICE, HOST, YOUR WELCOME SHOW: I'm no Mike Baker.

MONTGOMERY: Come on, man --

(CROSSTALK)

MALICE: -- with a dead cat apparently.

MONTGOMERY: I don't think he was talking about you.

MALICE: That's true.

MONTGOMERY: I want to read you Jimmy Carter's quote because I think -- I want to -- I want to get your feeling on this. He's talking about if they're under constant belief that the United States wants to attack them meaning North Korea even using nuclear weapons and that we are destroying their economy and they know that they're starving to death primarily because the United States withholds food aid for instance, just giving them surplus food that we can never use. I can understand how they feel.

MALICE: Well, let me give you a little bit of background about Jimmy Carter and North Korea. He went there in 1994 and tried to broker a deal with the great leader Kim Il-sung. And five years ago today I posted a quote from North Korean propaganda about their meeting and this is what they said Jimmy Carter said, "President Kim Il-sung is a person in whom George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and Abraham Lincoln, those popular three presidents of the United States early in its history are put together." So that actually did not happen. But the point is, North Korea withheld food from getting to its citizenry in the '90s because Kim Jong-il specifically said, if we allow the U.N. to feed the population, the government will be superfluous. So that's absolutely not true that they would be willing to accept food.

And if they did accept food, they would claim it's coming from the leader, so it's false in that regard. It's absolutely true that they think we're going to invade at any minute because you see people all over the news right now blatantly saying John Bolton had a -- entry in the Wall Street Journal that even South Korea is against it. We have the unilateral right to strike if they develop nuclear capabilities. And when President Bush said the axis of evil is Iran, Iraq, and North Korea. This is clearly a kill list of the three countries he wants to take out. So they are right to be afraid. And again, if most people in this country don't trust themselves to disarm and give up their guns and trust the federal government, why would the North Korean government thinking differently?

MONTGOMERY: And they have gotten so many resources over the years that they could have used to feed their people. I mean you don't build a multi- billion dollar nuclear weapons program unless you have money.

MALICE: And lastly, the have something called Sung Bun and the used food is a mechanism to control, so that the more loyal you are to the government, the more likely you are to receive food.

MONTGOMERY: And we're going to talk about that same thing happening in Venezuela. But I want to get back here because we've heard a lot about the Libyan model and it was something that John Bolton said in regards to denuclearizing North Korea, you know, which is essentially can be by force with a very sad ending for the leader of either Libya or North Korea. It wasn't just something that John Bolton said offhandedly months ago in an interview. This is now something that Vice President Pence has legitimized by using the same term. So do you think that we are on a march to war if in fact the meeting doesn't take place?

STEPHEN KENT, HOST, BELTWAY BANTHAS PODCAST: I don't think we're on a march to war. But I'm stunned that Mike Pence then echo that comment from John Bolton because that seemed incredibly ill-advice. They need to keep that comment and John Bolton off television for the next three weeks if they're going to make this meeting happen. He instills this sense of distrust with the North Korean regime. And Michael is absolutely right when he mentioned, you know, like trying to step away from their guns being their WMD's. Like -- they're like the cultists in Waco, like you cannot threaten them in this way. Their weapons are the only thing that make them feel secure, so this march towards total denuclearization or else is not going to work in this case. We need to be a little bit more gentle here.

MONTGOMERY: You know, I was talking to Gordon Chang a few weeks ago and he said they still have a conventional military which is actually a bigger practical threat to the region and it's much easier for them to go ahead and bomb South Korea. They don't -- they don't have to use nukes in order to inflict a lot of damage. So even if you take their nuclear program away, they still have the ability to defend themselves.

KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Right. That's always been the concern that they'll use artillery power against Seoul, South Korea which is right there across the border. This conversation you just had goes back to why this has never worked out and why very administration has had a failure when it comes to reining in North Korea's program. They are so far apart and although in the last couple of months we've seen things come together on the surface. When it comes to principles what the North Koreans are willing to do which is not giving up their nuclear arms, the negotiation now is about what denuclearization actually means and what the United States requires which is complete denuclearization of the peninsula. And the of course, there's China which is playing a role and saying, we can't ask North Korea to completely give up their nukes. However, we think that they should be limited in their capacity. And by the way, we don't want any of the fallout when it comes to the regime --

MONTGOMERY: No. China wants control and they want North Korea to be dependent and they also want to have as much influence as possible on the Korean Peninsula. My question is, does South Korea -- with South Korea and we're running out of time, so this has to beautiful quick answer. Would South Korea rather work with the United States in resolving this situation?

PAVLICH: I think ultimately, yes. I mean the United States is an ally. We're doing military excises. The United States has repeatedly said we are not taking military -- legal military exercises off the table in exchange for denuclearization of North Korea. But again, the gap here is very wide and it feels like we're back to the beginning of why this hasn't work out.

MONTGOMERY: That's where we five seconds.

PAVLICH: Katie gets it perfectly.

MONTGOMERY: Oh, very good, Michael Malice for taking the baton and looking very classily. The panel return a little bit later because how could they not. Plus, the plot thickens in the White House. Republican lawmakers now calling for a second special counsel to investigate the possibility the feds had politically motivated spies in the Trump campaign. And now the president has weighed in. I'll tell you what he said. Chris Stirewalt joins me next for reaction.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: We got news alert now. We just learned that the business partner of President Trump's former personal attorney Michael Cohen has agreed to cooperate with the government as part of a plea deal. Evgeny Friedman, I know I'm not saying that right. Is the note -- no. Michael Malice is shaking his head seriously. He's got a whiplash. He's a Russian immigrant known as the taxi king. Legal expert say this puts greater pressure on Cohen to cooperate with the Mueller probe, but the president says the real issue with the alleged spying on his campaign during the election. Watch.

TRUMP: A lot of people are saying they had spies in my campaign. If they had spies in my campaign, that would be a disgrace to this country. That would be one of the biggest insults that anyone has ever seen and it would be very illegal aside from everything else. It would make probably every political event ever look like small potatoes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Small potatoes? Delicious though. Michael Cohen cooperating with the government would certainly be no picnic for the president. But is he right to say the election spying is the biggest concern here. Joining me now Fox News Politics Editor Chris Stirewalt back in action. Welcome back.

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS POLITICS EDITOR: Ma'am.

MONTGOMERY: Indeed. All right. So let's talk about this. Spies in my campaign, is that the biggest issue of all if that is in fact true?

STIREWALT: The biggest issue in political history the president says --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: Maybe ever.

STIREWALT: Maybe ever which they're saying something. I mean the fall of Roman stuff was a pretty big deal. Look, the president says that there were spies, and this is a good narrative for him. This helps him with his base to talk about him as the real victim and the deep state, and it was really Obama and Clinton, and he's the victim here. He's not the perpetuator. But instead, he's the victim. And it -- and especially during a midterm where he desperately wants not to lose the house because that would create a whole new set of pressures on him in terms of investigations and conceivably impeachment that he wants to keep Republicans with him and a good way to do that is to say that he's not the offender here, that the system -- that he is the victim of the system.

MONTGOMERY: I truly believe that he believes he is not the offender. He believes he has done nothing wrong. And he's just, you know, as a negotiator does, if something doesn't succeed the first time you go about it from different angles. But is there something to this story? Is it possible that there were politically motivated operatives who were reaching out to people of on the Trump campaign getting information to give back to the FBI?

STIREWALT: Well, if they can put cheese in the can and have it spray out on a cracker that was anything --

MONTGOMERY: What a great invention.

STIREWALT: Anything is possible. But I don't know. I mean I cover politics. But I do know this that there is an inspector general's report that is in process about the investigation into Hillary Clinton's mishandling of state secrets. We're waiting for that in just the next coming days. And then hot on the heels of that one from the inspector general from the Department of Justice, Mr. Horowitz, is a report on the -- an investigation of the investigation into the Russian meddling and Trump's campaign, and that rashmitas. So I'm going to wait and find out, just like I'm going to wait and find out what Mueller actually has as opposed to all of these chatter dancing that people are doing around this stuff. I don't know. So I'm just going to wait until I find that.

MONTGOMERY: I mean if there was a coordinated effort between James Clapper and John Brennan and James Comey, you know, if that's not a politicized trifecta, I don't know from my politicized trifecta, and I have a menagerie of them in a green room.

STIREWALT: Well, look, if that was so and they conspired together against Donald Trump, well, that would be very bad. But we don't know that. We don't have that evidence just like we don't have evidence that the president colluded with Russia. We just have -- the best I can do at this point especially since we now have hopes that much of this will be concluded by the end of the summer. All I can do as a political forecaster is say, we'll have enough information to know how this is going to affect the midterms, how are Republicans going to respond to this.

MONTGOMERY: And I think the deployment of these types of informant is not only possible. I think it is plausible given the amount of -- the capability of these various organizations whether it's the NSA, or CIA, or FBI, or DEA spy on Americans. They have the tools. It would not surprise me if there are people who would abuse that power for their own benefit. And I hope that's not the case. I hope we live in a country where that kind of power is checked. So far Congress keeps codifying it and that is also terrifying. Chris Stirewalt, thank you so much.

STIREWALT: Ma'am.

MONTGOMERY: Bottom line and every day of the week young man. Very good.

STIREWALT: Quite so.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. Coming up, Venezuela, the hell hole where a month's salary can't even buy a cup of coffee. People are so hungry they resorted to eating zoo animals. They just re-elected their president with nearly 70 percent of the vote. Do you smell something fishy like a rotting zebra carcass? More examples of socialism destroying society in the monologue next. Stay here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: Crappy socialist dictator Nicolas Maduro was elected to another six-year term in Venezuela. Yes. And the equally corrupted authoritarian Turkish president campaigned for him, so they could share in the farcical fun. Leaders like Maduro, Erdogan, and Putin hate freedom because it gives filthy peasants too much they empower over their own lives. They liquidate government holdings to enrich themselves in their select cronies, and they steal from poor people who live horrible short lives before they die in squalor. It is no surprise these liberty loathers create an access of a-holes. They need to sow discord in the world's most powerful economy because a truly free market disrupts their tyrannical buggery -- signaling widespread discontent. President Trump has signed an executive order that bans U.S. citizens from snapping up Venezuelan bargains from the state fire sale. When people try to profit off this desperation, they are further imprisoning the poorest among them who cannot leave the country. There has been a mass exodus of doctors, nurses, teachers, engineers, and anyone else who has the means to escape the tightening news of cruel socialism. Anyone who can get out has fled, while those trapped there are enduring inflation that's already at nearly 14,000 percent. Plus, soaring malnutrition infant and maternal mortality rates that are also going up and are being undertreated at vacant hospitals. All fraudulent elections should be condemned, including those in Turkey and Russia. And we need to be doubly mindful not to indulge amateur socialist in this country. Because even though a Bernie Sanders presidency is a joke, the consequences of diet communism are deadly serious. And that's the memo.

Oh, hi, great to see me. That was swift. How long Nicolas Maduro possibly hang on to power as people are starving, his economy is ruined, the murder rate is one of the highest in the world, and all indicators suggest things are only going to get worse. So, what can we do to fix this failed socialist experiment before it turns into another Somalia? The party panel is back: Katie Pavlich, Stephen Kent, and Michael Malice. Katie, I don't think this is the worst-case-scenario. I don't think this is a black swan country undergoing some bad luck. I think this is the natural ultimate end of socialism and communism. What do you think?

PAVLICH: People argue, you know, this isn't real socialism or this isn't real communism. No, this is what it is. In 1999, Venezuela decide to go from more of a free market system to a socialist country to spend more money on welfare. This is exactly what we've seen as a result of that. Now, Maduro is out there this week, on video in this bizarre way -- waving to crowds that don't exist who applaud him on his re-election by 70 percent. The United States has condemned the election results. And the question is, where do we go from here? Not only in Venezuela but as the United States because there are American interests there and there are foreign policy implications of the regime collapsing. The Venezuelans are fleeing in large numbers. As you mentioned in your monologue that most of important people in the country who are, you know, doctors, nurses are leaving. But regular people are getting out because they are so desperate.

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: Giving on buses in getting out of the country.

PAVLICH: Liberals, socialist Utopia that is now existing in Venezuela as a result of these principles, not a mistake.

MONTGOMERY: Malice?

MALICE: What I would like to see happen because there's only so much we can do in Venezuela. Every politician who was a segregationist racist had to disavow, have to turn their backs, and had to be publicly humiliated, had to be (INAUDIBLE) for decades. So why are Michael Moore, and Bernie Sanders, and Jeremy Corbin in the U.K., all of the people who said Venezuela is a great thing, a great experiment, why do they not run on the public square and thrown tomatoes at where they go? You have children bleeding to death on hospital beds, you have people starving. Again, they shoot into crowds when people try to protest. To have anyone who's in politics for this, not take responsibility for it, and still begin a microphone, I think, is disgraceful.

MONTGOMERY: Yes, you're absolutely right. And it's only getting worse, and worse, and worse. It's actually getting exponentially worse as inflation rises, and the poorest people, they are the ones who can't afford to feed their kids. They never had to treat malnutrition five years ago. And now that condition has gone up 100 folds in hospitals that we have no doctors. So, what do we do? Do we do anything as the United States?

KENT: Well, there's again, limited tools in our tool kit to deal with this situation. We're not going to invade Venezuela. We shouldn't. And sanctions are something that we have to be delicate with as well, because we want to target the elite in that country who are abusing and starving their people without then, actually, hurting the people who live in that country and are not able to leave. We are mentioning that doctors and everyone who are able to flee. You know, the oil industry runs basically the only leftover economy that's there, but it only benefits the wealthy.

MONTGOMERY: Yes, that's absolutely right. And that's what they did. I mean, it is a state-run industry. They've got so much oil, which was great, and they were profitable when oil prices were high. But when they tanked --

MALICE: This is atlas shrugged comes to life. This is exactly the (INAUDIBLE). Take out excessive business having the government running, and then how long it takes for people to be --

MONTGOMERY: And you know, when atlas shrugged, that's when the people are holding up the economy, they leave. They're exhausted.

MALICE: And if the poor and the weak were the first to suffer.

MONTGOMERY: That's absolutely right and suffer the longest. Well, back here at home, I mean, we're really suffering, right? Because House Speaker Paul Ryan is facing renewed pressure to step down from his perch before his term ends. The administration maybe nudging the effort along. White House Budget Director, Mick Mulvaney, reportedly said he has spoken with House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy about ousting Ryan, adding: "Wouldn't it be great to force a Democrat running in a tight race to have to put up or shut up about voting for Nancy Pelosi eight weeks before an election. That's a really, really good vote for us to force if we can figure out how to do it." Now, Mulvaney says he's supportive of the speaker. And McCarthy said he's never even talked to Mulvaney about it. So, should House Republicans plan a mutiny, Katie?

MALICE: We always hear word of a mutiny whenever there's any kind of speakers raised. Jim Jordan, other than the hundred conservatives that came out and sign the letters saying they want him to run for speaker. Paul Ryan will likely out his term as speaker of the house.

MONTGOMERY: He's not going to get pushed out of the way?

PAVLICH: You know, I don't know. I mean, the thing is, as they say in Washington, D.C.: if you want a friend, get a dog. And although, Kevin McCarthy and Paul Ryan have been very close for the last couple of years, not only just in leadership as Paul Ryan came out through the ranks in the House, from the Ways and Means Committee. I doubt that McCarthy is going to actually push Paul Ryan out.

MONTGOMERY: They want Jim to working at job.

KENT: No, money talks. Paul Ryan brought in 11.9 million in the first quarter of the Republican.

MONTGOMERY: Yes, that's why Nancy Pelosi is still around.

KENT: So, yes, put up or shut up. Everybody else who wants that job. They're not going to move him out as long as they need to raise money for these mid-term elections which are going to be contentious. I also would like to see Paul Ryan finish out this job because we need, we need him to finish and have a legitimate open-run election. Kevin McCarthy cannot be nominated for this. Nobody really wants him in the Republican --

MONTGOMERY: Is there a benefit to chaos?

MALICE: Look at the last Republican speaker. You have ambassador of the Vatican's wife, you have this lobster who's selling marijuana. Dennis Hastert, we can't even discuss on air. And now, we have the guy who Mitt Romney made his beta. So, this is quite a cast of characters.

MONTGOMERY: He is his Robin.

MALICE: Yes.

MONTGOMERY: Yes, he really is. I love Paul Rhino. I love the term Paul Rhino. I think Paul Ryan has completely turned his back on his principles.

MALICE: But in 2012, Romney needed to play the base, and he chose Ryan. And that's how far the Republican Party has gone to the right, but even Ryan is regardless of the left --

MONTGOMERY: Yes, Ryan and a slap on the base. You know, I want to thank you all for being here, because you are good friends, you are allies of freedom, and you are delightful people.

PAVLICH: Thank you for having us.

MONTGOMERY: Freedoms and my feels. Michael, Stephen, and Katie Pavlich, thank you all. Coming up, Cops say Amazon's new facial recognition technology is helping them identify suspects in crime. But the privacy police are sounding alarm bells. Emily Compagno joins me with the details. Hi, Emily! She's coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: The future is now. And I don't know if I like it. Amazon has some fancy new facial recognition technology and they're selling it to police departments for $6.00 a month. What could possibly go wrong? Well, a lot. Which is why the ACLU is asking the tech giant to stop marketing the tool to law enforcement agencies -- fearing it could be used to invade your privacy. Amazon respond to the ACLU's request with a statement that read in quote: "Amazon requires the customers comply with the law and be responsible when they use Amazon Web Service (AWS). When we find that AWS services are being abused by a customer, we suspend that customer's right to use our services." Now, I would never add the cape for government regulation to fix a problem like this, but should we be concerned about our civil liberties and privacy when a tech giant like amazon combines with government? Let me ask former Criminal Defense Attorney and Legal Analyst, Emily Compagno, she is in Seattle, where Amazon is headquartered. Emily, welcome back to the show.

EMILY COMPAGNO, CRIMINAL DEFENSE ATTORNEY AND LEGAL ANALYST: So, let's discuss this. What is the down side to selling facial recognition technology on the cheap to law enforcement?

COMPAGNO: Right. ACLU and others are arguing, look, there's a high capacity for abuse here. So, they argue this isn't akin to just an extension of photography. They say, this is akin to walking through mass protests and asking for identification for every single person there. They argue this can be used to follow immigrants by ICE, this can be used to identify any random person on a street corner. So, they kind of have the same arguments that they have for all existing surveillance programs, which is where is the limit, right? And they argue that, although it's not different from other facial recognition program. Here, they site that what is problematic is Amazon's aggressive marketing to law enforcement agencies and the fact that the reach is so prolific. So, that's what they're arguing here.

MONTGOMERY: And that's one of things that has always concerned me, whether it's Amazon, Facebook, Google, or any other social media platform. You know, these big tech companies getting in bed with the government, whether it's military or law enforcement, the consequences can be dire. They're not always dire. We want our law enforcement agencies to have tools and have technology so they can keep us safe. The problem is when these things malfunction. My iPhone X recognizes my face about half the time, and it's not because I'm a supermodel but a lot of people say that. It's because this technology isn't perfect. And you know, I don't trust that the facial recognition software wouldn't recognize the wrong person.

COMPAGNO: Right. Which is part of the argument and, you know, on the other side, law enforcement agencies are arguing: look, you know, we're not there yet. It's important to us that the community understands what it's being used for just as crucially as what it's not. And they site the fact that, you know, this has been used for surveillance footage matching from burglaries, from what's picked up from CCTV. They argue this has been used to find abducted children or missing children in amusement parks. It was even used actually this weekend at the royal wedding of now duke and duchess of Sussex for what royals had attended, right? Sky News used. So, it's important that they feel the community that they --

MONTGOMERY: I want to know the difference between David Beckham and Serena Williams. Because there were some people on other networks who didn't really know the difference. And that's a wonderful private application of that tool essentially for entertainment. I don't want to be arrested for a crime that Kate Upton has committed because we look so similar.

COMPAGNO: Yes, and I do want to point out, though, that there's a bit of hyperbole I see here in terms of the narrative that these free speech firms and companies are pushing forward. And here's one in particular, they cite that this can now be used at airports which is a public place, they argue. We're now in this climate of protesting and robust participation. They claim that there could be a chilling factor, but I want to point out that airports for example are not public places for purposes of free speech. It's been long held at the first, second, and fourth amendment are actually restricted there. So, in terms of the conversation surrounding this, to me it's important that the narrative isn't subjects to that kind of hyperbolic quality, because to me, it just increases the chasm between law enforcement and what they're trying to do, and then lawful protected right to privacy that we have without kind of muddying the water.

MONTGOMERY: Absolutely, understand. And I think there is so much more to discuss and address here. I really appreciate your perspective. Thank you so much, Emily. Great to talk to you again.

COMPAGNO: Thank you.

MONTGOMERY: "TOPICAL STORM" is next. It's a good one. Stay here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: The NYPD is looking for a group of gunmen who robbed a Walgreen's pharmacy while wearing clown masks. Witnesses say, there could be as many as 15 of them. They were last seen fleeing one tiny car. Be on the lookout for a many, because this is the "TOPICAL STORM."

Topic number one. We begin tonight in Houston, Texas, where everybody knows that if you're going to drive on the highway, you're going to need plenty of horse power. Look at this. Oh, mercy! The Belmont state aren't for another three weeks but this fellow is already getting in a good workout. In any other state, the sight of horse on a highway might have caused a 12-car pile-up. But in (INAUDIBLE) they're like, it's probably going out for more beer. Anything a couple of cars high beams so, they could pass. Now, fortunately some good Samaritans were able to steer it off the road, and police have since returned though, of course, to its owner but not before issuing a ticket for using the carpooling without a passenger. Rules are rules, pal. Get a (INAUDIBLE) next time.

Topic number two. There it is. A Florida City issued a zombie alert to its citizens. And we'd like to think it was an accident, but you never know in Florida. A storm caused a blackout on Sunday that led the residents of Lake Worth, Florida, to get an alert that read: Zombie -- power outage and zombie alert for the residents of Lake Worth and Terminus. There are now far less than 7300 customers involved due to extreme zombie activity. Now, Terminus is a fictitious town from the hit T.V. show "The Walking Dead". Its inclusion in the message led cops to believe it was a prank. Great police, fellows. Well done. It's unlikely someone confused the state of Florida and "The Walking Dead" because the two couldn't be more different. One is an apocalyptic wasteland of human oddities, and the other is a T.V. show. That's right.

Topic number three. If you're a cop in the city of Cleveland, long enough you'll see everything -- except for a Browns Super Bowl championship. But these cops, they don't need a championship to party. The officers responded to this block party to cut the noise, but they wound up cutting a rug because not even a horse can resist it. It's so addictive. We have a staffer named Courtney who does it all the time in the office. She's very special. The video of the dancing cops has taken off across the country, and so has their other police horse. There I go again on my own. Turns out he'll be shuffling papers behind his desk because he's been suspended for not tying up his horse.

Topic number four. There it is. Thanks to Bunk Breaker for this one. Women's soccer legend, Brandy Chastain, was inducted into the Bay Area hall of fame this week. But the person who may brand these flack, must drink a few brandies before going into the studio. The women's soccer legend became famous for whipping off her jersey after hitting the winning penalty kick in the 1999 World Cup. She was an international (INAUDIBLE), but apparently, she's now a trucker named Gill, who likes beef jerky and lot lizard. The Internet says she looks like Gary Busey, so either way slice it, she's looks like someone who is little nuts. She looks like she's a transitioning Elizabeth Warren without glasses. You can't make this up, unlike Elizabeth's heritage. The hall of fame has since apologized and offered to make a new plaque. And perhaps, not surprisingly Brandi, has graciously accepted their offer. We reached out to the plaque maker for comment but he was at the vet with his seeing eye dog.

Topic number five. Perhaps no athlete is more disappointed than Tonya Harding who did not win the top prize in last night's "Dancing with the Stars" finale. Someday, historians will remember this as the end of the #kneetoo movement. Figure skater Adam Rippon took home the win, and Lord knows he'll need the prize money, because competing against Tonya Harding can cost you an arm and a leg. If you don't believe me, ask Nancy Kerrigan. NFL Star, Josh Norman, with the other runner-up in the first all-athlete season. It was also the first season of all famous people. Usually, that show is a who's who of people that make you say, who? Her T.V. comeback may be over, but don't feel bad for Tonya because she just joined a new dance troupe who are very familiar with her work. Is he going to get the police? (INAUDIBLE) felony. If only she had this much rhythm in last night's finale. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: Thank you so much for watching this show tonight. I am your tender flower. It is the best hour of your day and mine. You can follow me on Twitter and Instagram, @KennedyNation; on Facebook, KennedyFBN -- load it up for hate mail on Thursday; E-mail kennedyfbn@foxbusiness.com Tomorrow night on the show, Congressman Ron Desantis, Kayleigh McEnany is back, and Shannon Bream. She's a Bream come true. I can't wait. I will see you tomorrow night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: A Texas Model railway...

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do you have any idea what Steve spent to put this together?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I've always heard $1 million.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

END

urn:contentItem:5SD9-P5V1-DY0W-42PY-00000-00Trump Says Summit with North Korea's Kim Jong-un May Be Delayed; North Korea Allows South Korea Reporters to Visit Nuclear Site, Official Says; Crisis In Venezuela; White House Speaker Paul Ryan Facing New Pressure To Step Down; Amazon Is Selling Facial Recognition Technology To Law Enforcement2018-05-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:59ZLexisNexisTrump Says Summit with North Korea's Kim Jong-un May Be Delayed; North Korea Allows South Korea Reporters to Visit Nuclear Site, Official Says; Crisis In Venezuela; White House Speaker Paul Ryan Facing New Pressure To Step Down; Amazon Is Selling Facial Recognition Technology To Law EnforcementLanhamFULL TEXT

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good night from New York.

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: All right. Let's take a live look and listen to President Trump. He's speaking at the Susan B. Anthony List 11th Annual Campaign for Life Gala at the National Building Museum in Washington, D.C. Let's go.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I watch him all the time. I don't know him well, but I'll get to know him. John Rutherford, where is he, John? Central casting. Great job, John. He's always defending me. Actually, most of you are always defending me and that's OK. And from my neck of the woods, Claudia Kenny. Thank you, Claudia. Thank you. And for those many that I have left out, I'm sorry. But I say, give me a totally complete list and I will call you tomorrow and I will apologize personally. All right. But every day between now and November, we must work together to elect more lawmakers who share our values, cherish our heritage, and proudly stand for life. And that is a great group of people I introduced. I can tell you that. We're also glad to be joined by a beloved member of my administration, a true fighter for faith and family, and your 2018 distinguished leader, Kellyanne Conway. Kellyanne. What a job --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Sorry. The president of course speaking introduction luminaries there at the gala and we will dip back in if there is some breaking news or he stumbles upon something that you need to hear about it because you got it right here, baby. There have been some major twists in President Trump's scheduled meeting with Kim Jong-un. The president saying he no longer likes the North Korean dictator's attitude and casting doubt that the meeting will happen at all. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If it doesn't happen, maybe it will happen later. Maybe it will happen at a different time. But we will see. But we are talking. The meeting is scheduled as you know on June 12th in Singapore. And whether or not it happens, you'll be knowing pretty soon, but we're talking right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Talking may not be good enough. We're being told Kim Jong-un may have second thoughts about giving up all of his nuclear weapons. The president today said the dictator would be making a huge mistake by walking away from this all-important table. And just yesterday, Vice President Pence told our own Martha MacCallum that if he keeps his nukes, the situation could end really, really badly. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It would be a great mistake for Kim Jong-un to think he could play Donald Trump. The truth is that President Trump has made it clear that this administration will not tolerate the regime in North Korea possessing nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles that threaten our people, that threaten the United States of America , that threaten our allies in the region.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: The vice president went on to say that North Korea will end up like Libya if it doesn't make a deal. And we all remember how that ended. The country was destroyed. Muammar Gaddafi was murdered in the street by rebels. Wow. So will Kim Jong-un play ball or is the meeting and the possible Nobel Prize out the window? With me now Fox Business Reporter Edward Lawrence with all the details. Edward.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well, Kennedy, this is the first time that we're hearing the president actually say that the meeting may not go forward on June 12th. However, the State Department is saying that they are working towards that date and only that date.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF STATE: I do have a real sense that he would -- he would find American investment, American technology, American know how of real value to his people. If we get this right and we get the denuclearization right, America wouldn't be quite capable of delivering them with lots of things that would make life better for the North Korean people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And President Trump saying that he personally guarantees the safety of Kim Jong-un at the meeting in Singapore. He president going on to say that he recognizes that fact that Kim Jong-un would be the person to lead his people into the future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I would say that we are looking certainly right now at two Koreas, two very successful Koreas. You're going to have a very, very successful North Korea and you're going to have a very successful and you already do, South Korea.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now, all of this is predicated on denuclearization. And right now, there's a group of journalists from the United States, from China, Russia, and the United Kingdom that are expected to witness the North Koreans actually taking down, demolishing one of their nuclear sites. Now, whether in the area has delayed that trip. It is expected to happen again today or tomorrow their time, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: Yes, same thing. Edward, thank you so much. All right. So Kim -- can Kim Jong-un be trusted to keep his word? And is China throwing a monkey wrench into the work? That question answers itself. It certainly is fuzz bud. Just let me bring in former CIA operative Mike Baker, also the President of Diligence LLC. Welcome back to the show, Mike.

MIKE BAKER, PRESIDENT, DILIGENCE LLC: Thank you very much, Kennedy. Thank you.

MONTGOMERY: Absolutely. The president says that Kim Jong-un's attitude needs an adjustment since his most of recent chat with President Xi Jinping. What do you think about China's meddling in a situation they're not necessarily a part of?

BAKER: Well, in that you just -- that last part of your sentence is important to note. What China wants to insure is that they're relevant in these conversations. And they made that fairly clear over the past couple of months. But, look, nobody is surprised by sort of the posturing that's taking place on both sides leading into this. This is an historic potentially defining moment. Even if the summit occurs and nothing happens after that and we can't get through the lengthy negotiations to get some type of deal signed, just getting to this point almost being at the table is an historic moment given how many years we've spent kicking the can down the road with a fairly feckless foreign policy towards North Korea. So I think that the administration has been pretty clear in stating that they understand this could be problematic and saying they're going to walk away from the table. It is interesting to note that aside from the fact you can't swing a dead cat without hitting a North Korea expert these days. It's also interesting to know that you got members of the resistance and some members of the media who seemed almost hoping for this thing to fall apart. And if you find yourself rooting against peace on the peninsula because you don't like President Trump, then you might want to rethink your priorities.

MONTGOMERY: I absolutely agree with you about that. And I think there is a time and a place for resistance. I think there are certainly instances where you have to hold the president accountable for the things the he says and does. But here I think, you know, this is an area where we have to be as supportive as possible because a peaceful ending to this situation is critical. It's paramount. Now, what's interesting and something that you have pointed out is obviously there are issues with the Iran deal. And you have noted that part of the issue is because President Obama was so impatient, and he was so dead set on landing that deal that he really compromise our position there. So would you caution this president against doing the same thing with North Korea?

BAKER: Right. And, again, they've been very been clear in saying over the past many weeks that they'd be willing to get up from the table and walk away. But what they have to be careful about is as you get closer and closer to that potential meeting on the 12th of June, you have to be careful that you feel so invested in this now, and you -- you're so keen to get this going. But you have to step back, take a breath, and understand that, as you said, the previous administration, the Obama administration, you know, they had their knickers in such a twist over the desire to get a deal, any deal, that they were willing to overlook the problems with the deal and they were willing to accept all the requests and concessions and demands that the Iranian regime put into that deal. And so, you know, and again, with anything that takes place in this world of weapons agreements whether you're talking about conventional weapons, nuclear weapons, biological or chemical weapons really at the end of the day what matters more than anything else is verification.

Trust but verify. If you can't verify and the Iranian example is a good one because it was in the deal. We were not allowed to inspect military sites. So, yes, were they complying as people who were supporting that the deal say? Well, they were complying with it. Yes, we got -- they were complying with what was written in the deal. But we had no verification capability for any of their military sites. And frankly, that's like saying you're a serial killer. You allow the police to come into your home and search it, but you can't go in the basement and look around. So we get to be really careful and if we do get to that hard difficult point where we're actually trying to pen a deal. If we can't get verification locked down with this, we didn't have it with the Syrian chemical issue. We didn't have it in the past on occasion with the Russians --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: -- trust Russia because they said they got rid of all Syria's chemical weapons. And he also said that we're fine in Iran because he read the deal, and it's super solid, and they have no desire to manufacture any fissile material or use those in drills to make big --

(CROSSTALK)

BAKER: That was their investment. They were so -- they were so keen as you pointed out. So keen to get that deal, so we have to be careful. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I've always heard $1 million.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

END
