urn:contentItem:5X16-0N11-JB20-G1JF-00000-00Trump Says Talks With Taliban Are "Dead"; Judiciary Committee To Define Impeachment Probe; Trump Rallies Support For North Carolina GOP Candidate; Paper Blames Trump Rallies For Spikes In Hate Crimes; Dems' Stats On Trump Rallies Turn Out To Be False; ICE Identifies Six Suspects As Members Of MS-13; 50 States, Territories Target Google In Anti-Trust Probe; E.U. Regulators Have Fined Google $5 Billion For Tactics; Shannon Hears About The Life And Loves Of The Delaneys2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:59ZLexisNexisFOX NEWS @ NIGHT11:00 PM ESTJosh Schwerin, Robert Ehrlich, Ken PaxtonNEWSDomestic090901cb.259Trump Says Talks With Taliban Are "Dead"; Judiciary Committee To Define Impeachment Probe; Trump Rallies Support For North Carolina GOP Candidate; Paper Blames Trump Rallies For Spikes In Hate Crimes; Dems' Stats On Trump Rallies Turn Out To Be False; ICE Identifies Six Suspects As Members Of MS-13; 50 States, Territories Target Google In Anti-Trust Probe; E.U. Regulators Have Fined Google $5 Billion For Tactics; Shannon Hears About The Life And Loves Of The DelaneysLaura Ingraham, Mike Emanuel, Gillian Turner, David Spunt, Jonathan Serrie, Marc Thiessen, Trace Gallagher, Jeff Paul, Hillary Vaughn, Jack Keane

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST: And the third trimester abortion stuff are really revealing themselves. Unbelievable. Good for Tulsi Gabbard, for at least coming out against that.

All right. Up next, Mike Emanuel in for Shannon Bream and the "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" team, will all take it from here. Mike.

MIKE EMANUEL, FOX NEWS HOST: Thanks so much, Laura. We begin with a Fox News Alert.

As Democrats push ahead on the so-called impeachment inquiry against him, President Trump presses ahead with a MAGA rally aimed at proving his support in bellwether districts is as strong as ever heading into 2020. Which side has the political upper hand ahead of a key test for the president's political power? Stick around to find out.

Also tonight, retired four-star general, General Jack Keane is standing by live to tell us what he knows about the Taliban talks at Camp David that fell apart. He'll tell us how to end America's longest war and bring our troops home from Afghanistan.

Plus, Texas' attorney general, Ken Paxton, is leading the charge against Google and its, quote, "monopolistic behavior." Almost every state is joining the massive antitrust investigation. This is just the latest effort in the crackdown on big tech and how America rains in the industry's power.

Could Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Apple be facing new restrictions? We'll debate. Hello and welcome to Fox News @ Night. I'm Mike Emanuel in for Shannon Bream. We begin tonight in Fayetteville, North Carolina. Correspondent Jonathan Serrie is at President Trump's rally. Good evening, Jonathan.

JONATHAN SERRIE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening to you, Mike. President Trump had hoped to tour storm damage from hurricane Dorian in advance of tonight's rally. Thunderstorms in the area along the North Carolina coast prevented him from doing that, but he did receive a briefing onboard Air Force One. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I've just come from a meeting with North Carolina officials representing communities hit by hurricane Dorian and I expressed the unwavering solidarity of the American people. We are behind you 100 percent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SERRIE: Tonight's rally comes on the eve of a special election in North Carolina's ninth Congressional district. Republican, Dan Bishop, entered the race after state election officials refused to certify last year's contest amid allegations of ballot tampering. President Trump hopes to tip the balance of this tight race.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Our first task is a giant victory tomorrow, right here in the great state of North Carolina. With your support, tomorrow, we take the first steps to firing Speaker Pelosi and winning back the House in 2020.

SEN. DAN BISHOP (R-NC), CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: What's going to happen tomorrow, on Tuesday September 10th, is the ninth district is going to send the Congressman with backbone who can stand up to the smears and the lies of the lying fake news media and support the president of the United States as he keeps America great.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SERRIE: Ahead of this evening's rally, Democrat, Dan McCready, was also in Fayetteville. The Marine veteran held the Get-out-to-Vote rally with military families and went door-to-door campaigning.

Today, McCready tweeted, "No one should go to Washington as a Democrat first or a Republican first. They should go as Americans first. That's why I stood with fellow veterans from both parties to say, let's work across the aisle to lower health care costs and get the job done for North Carolinians."

Mike, both parties have been watching this race very closely as a potential indicator of what to expect in 2020. They've been testing out various messages with voters to see what resonates most. Mike?

EMANUEL: Jonathan Serrie leading us off in battleground North Carolina. Jonathan, thanks a lot.

Lawmakers returning to the nation's capital and Congressional Democrats in the House and Senate are setting some big goals to accomplish. Topping the list in the House, figuring out a way to potentially move forward on impeaching President Trump.

Correspondent David Spunt is here now. Good evening, David.

DAVID SPUNT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Mike, minutes after getting back into the swing of things, House Democrats began moving forward with consideration of an impeachment probe.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SPUNT: After a six-week recess, Congress is back in session and the Judiciary Committee, chaired by New York Congressman, Jerry Nadler, is preparing to consider an impeachment probe.

REP. JERRY NADLER (D-NY): I think the resolution speaks for itself if you read it.

SPUNT: Chairman Nadler announced a Thursday vote to set the rules for any future impeachment-type hearings. He calls it, "The next step," in determining, "Whether to recommend articles of impeachment."

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi who has cautioned the use of the "I" word in the past, said this exclusively to Fox News tonight.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do you support the resolution that Chairman Nadler has put forward?

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA): Yes, I do. I think that you should characterize it for what it is, it's a continuation of what we have been doing and how we all work together on these things.

SPUNT: But this doesn't mean the House Speaker is in favor of impeachment. Nadler's resolution simply lays out procedures for a, "Impeachment investigation." Republicans don't seem fazed.

REP. DOUG COLLINS (R-GA): They know they don't have the votes to go for a full formal impeachment inquiry, which is what our House rules require. So what they're doing is they're going to try and change our rules.

SPUNT: Other Democrats are probing Vice President Mike Pence's stay at the president's property in Doonbeg, Ireland last week. Pence was on official business and traveled 180 miles for meetings in Dublin. And the Air Force is internally reviewing travel policies after a cruise spent time at the president's Scotland resort, Trump Turnberry, while on official business.

TRUMP: I own a lot of different places. Soon, you'll find that out. Because I'll be, at some point, prior to the election, I'm going to be giving out a financial report of me and it'll be extremely complete.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SPUNT: House Democrats also announced an investigation into allegations that the Trump reelection campaign is using the Ukrainian justice system to its advantage to hurt Joe Biden's campaign. No word from the Trump campaign tonight on that specific allegation. Mike.

EMANUEL: David Spunt live in Washington. David, thanks a lot.

Does this impeachment push here in Washington playing into the president's hands or well out in places like faithful North Carolina where the president said this about his Democratic opponents?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: A vote for any Democrat in 2020 and a vote for any Democrat tomorrow in North Carolina is a vote for the rise of radical socialism and the destruction of the American dream.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: Let's turn to the former national spokesperson for Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign, Josh Schwerin, and Fox News contributor, Marc Thiessen. Gentlemen, great to have you.

JOSH SCHWERIN, COMMS DIRECTOR, PRIORIES USA: Good to be with you.

EMANUEL: Josh, let me play this for you from Ohio Republican Congressman, Jim Jordan, and I will get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Look, the Michael Cohen hearing didn't work out the way they wanted, the John Dean hearing didn't work out the way they wanted, and of course, the Bob Mueller hearing and that investigation didn't work out the way they wanted, but that doesn't stop them. They're going to continue to push this ridiculous impeachment narrative.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: So, Josh, what about the argument that it's time for Democrats to move on?

SCHWERIN: Democrats can do multiple things. They can do their constitutional duty to get out to oversight of the Executive Branch, and they can introduce policy.

Today, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi were calling on the Senate to put forth legislation on background checks, which is 80 percent support, 90 percent support. Later in the week, I believe, they're going to introduce legislation on drug pricing. So they are doing both things.

If you remember, Republicans when they had control of the House, they took the majority in January of 2011. By February, they were already investigating Obama. After that point, there was not a single day of Obama's presidency where the Republicans did not have an investigation open.

The fact is, you can investigate and legislate at the same time and the Republicans are just hypocritical because they're afraid of what people might find, and Donald Trump's afraid of it.

EMANUEL: But it seems like all the impeachment talk really eats up a lot of the oxygen in this town. Let's take a listen to judiciary Democrat, Steve Cohen, and then I will get you guys to weigh in on that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. STEVE COHEN (D-TN): Like they did in Nixon, it was 17 percent when they started their hearings, over 60 percent when the hearings were concluded. Is there a smoking gun? I think there's an arsenal, a garrison. It proves out there that we'll be in a good spot in December and the public will find that they've been taken for a ride.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: Marc, is this push by House Democrats going to grow in public support?

MARC THIESSEN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: No. Look, the Democrats of the party that cried collusion. For two years, they told us Donald Trump had colluded with Russia, that Trump was a traitor, that he was a Russian agent, conspired with the Russians to undermine our democracy, and those were serious accusations and the American people took them seriously, and so we had a special counsel who investigated it, we spent tens of millions of dollars and it turned out it was nothing more than a conspiracy theory. It never happened, he didn't do it.

And so what's happening now is the Democrats failed to do what they wanted to, which is to depose a sitting president with these Trumped up charges of collusion and they're shifting gears to other things. One, they have no credibility because they lied to the American people about collusion and misled them.

And second of all, they're not listening to the American people. After the Mueller probe, Harris Poll found 65 percent of Americans say they should not have impeachment proceedings. Fifty percent said given the Mueller report, we should turn the page and investigations of Trump. And 80 percent said they want their Congressional representatives working on infrastructure, health care, immigration, rather than investigations to the president.

They are not listening to the American people. And every day that they focused on investigations instead of their agenda, and that's leading the news, is a bad day for the Democratic Party.

EMANUEL: Josh, tonight, President Trump warned supporters about the rise of radical socialism and that a vote for, "Any Democrat" was like supporting the destruction of the American dream. Your response?

SCHWERIN: We've been hearing socialism attacks against Democrats for 50 years. I can say in my organization, Priorities USA, does a lot of polling about the states. This attack doesn't work. The fact is what we're talking about in states right now is health care, Medicare, Social Security, the trade war that Trump is bankrupting farmers with.

Those are the issues that voters want to hear about and that's what Democrats are talking about right now. And the fact is Trump has given up on winning over the middle, so he just uses this red meat rhetoric that we've heard for decades to gin up his base, because he wants to scare people, but it's not going to work.

THIESSEN: Except it's true now. I mean, you're -- when Bill Clinton -- you worked for Hillary Clinton, you're a Clinton person. Bill Clinton said the era of big government is over. Today's message of the Democratic Party is the ear of big government is back. They're proposing literally over $100 million in new -- if you had a Medicare for All, Green New Deal, all the climate plans, all the free health care, free college, free everything in terms of loan forgiveness for students, literally, more than the entire national debt.

So the idea that somehow that this is because Republicans have been saying socialism for years, it's actually true.

EMANUEL: All right. Marc Thiessen, Josh Schwerin, thanks for your time, gentlemen.

SCHWERIN: Thank you.

EMANUEL: Fox News Alert. President Trump says peace talks with the Taliban are dead and Afghans are preparing for a new wave of violence.

Tonight, we're learning more about what led to the collapse of these month- long talks. Here's Correspondent, Gillian Turner. Good evening, Gillian.

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Mike. So after a week of will they won't, the immediate speculation, President Trump announced via Twitter, this weekend, he canceled with the chatter chat with the Afghan Taliban at Camp David.

So now, after nearly 18 years, 2,300 American lives, and $900 billion, some top military brass insist the war in Afghanistan is still worth fighting.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GENERAL DAVID PETRAEUS, FORMER AFGHANISTAN COALITION COMMANDER: I think the president very much made the right call. Again, we went for a reason, and we have stayed for a reason. That's to ensure that Al Qaeda and now the Islamic state, which has moved in as well to try to exploit the situation cannot reestablish the sanctuary.

TURNER: The ill-fated meeting between President Trump and Taliban leadership, fell apart, after facing resistance from key White House officials including National Security Advisor, John Bolton.

Now, Republican and Democratic lawmakers are lining up to denounce the president's decision to schedule the meeting in the first place.

Key senators from his own party say the very idea of negotiations should be a nonstarter as long as Taliban fighters have American blood on their hands.

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R-LA): We shouldn't be negotiating with a group that's killing young Americans at the same time.

TURNER: Other lawmakers say the leader of the free world's country home should be off-limits to America's enemies.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I would not have them at Camp David, I would not have them in the United States.

TURNER: Still, others are crying foul on timing, pointing out at the meeting was slated just three days before 9/11.

SEN. MITT ROMNEY (R-UT): It's pretty clear the Taliban is not a reliable negotiating party. It would be my choice to have them come to Camp David really now.

TURNER: Key Democrats say these kinds of last-minute switcheroos are becoming a hallmark of President Trump's foreign policy.

SEN. BOB MENENDEZ (D-NJ): Whether it's with Kim Jong-un, whether it's in this case of the Taliban, whether it was with our closest allies or some of our most fierce adversaries like Russia, is that there is no strategic plan by the administration.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TURNER: Talks with the North Koreans have stopped and started and fits over the past year, now the White House is gearing up to reengage with Iran over at the U.N. later this month to gin up what President Trump calls a better nuclear deal.

Also developing tonight, Mike, a senior administration source confirms to Fox News, President Trump is still looking to get out of Afghanistan completely as soon as possible. Mike?

EMANUEL: All right. We'll keep watching it. Gillian Turner, thanks a lot.

TURNER: You bet.

EMANUEL: Do MAGA rallies like tonight leads to hate crimes? New evidence, next.

Plus, a brutal Baltimore murder case, six of the seven people charged identified is being part of the deadly MS-13 gang, and in the country illegally, former governor of Maryland, Robert Ehrlich joins us, next.

EMANUEL: Tonight, two Harvard academics are calling into question the validity of a paper published in The Washington Post back in March, that claims a massive spike in hate crimes in counties where President Trump has hosted campaign rallies. Our chief breaking news correspondent Trace Gallagher is looking into it, tonight. Good evening, Trace.

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CHIEF BREAKING NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Mike. The paper was written by three Texas A&M professors who claim that during the 2016 presidential campaign, counties that hosted Trump rallies, saw a jump in hate crimes of 226 percent.

The paper was never published, peer-reviewed, or thoroughly fact-checked, and yet, made its way into The Washington Post. From there, it got prominent play on just about every liberal media outlet.

t was also used to attack the president by Democrats like Bernie Sanders and Congress member Ilhan Omar, who cited the numbers and wrote "assaults increase when cities host Trump rallies. Your rhetoric is directly and indirectly inciting hate, Mr. President."

Except, the numbers were wrong. Last week, Reason published a piece by two Harvard PhD students who will look at the claims made by the Texas A&M professors, replicated the results, and found that, oops, the conclusions were based on a mistake.

In fact, to double check the mistake, the Harvard students used the same method to analyze the effects of Hillary Clinton's campaign rallies and found they actually led to a higher jump in hate crimes than Trump rallies.

But here's the problem, the Texas A&M professors simply compared counties with rallies to counties without. They forgot to factor in the size of the counties and candidates tend to campaign in bigger counties.

So, Orange County, California and its 3 million people got the same weight as Orange County, Indiana, population, 19,000. The mathematic equation basically went like this; Orange County, California had two Trump rallies and five hate incidents, Orange County, Indiana had no Trump rallies and no hate incidents. Therefore, Trump breeds hate.

But after controlling for the disparity in population, bottom line is that neither Trump nor Clinton's rallies sparked hate crimes. And the Harvard students add that because academics and journalists are largely liberal, they were eager to pounce on the anti-Trump conclusion.

Had the initial study found the Clinton campaign inciting hate, many believe The Washington Post would have fact-checked until the Pinocchios were running off the page. Mike.

EMANUEL: Trace Gallagher, thanks for breaking it down for us. GALLAGHER: Yes.

EMANUEL: Fox News Alert, six of the seven people charged in a stabbing death of a man in Maryland have been identified as part of the deadly street gang MS-13 and are reportedly in the county, in this country, illegally. Joining me now is a former Republican governor of Maryland, Robert Ehrlich, Governor, great to have you.

ROBERT EHRLICH, FORMER GOVERNOR OF MARYLAND: Mike, how are you doing? Good to be back with you.

EMANUEL: Thank you. President Trump spoke this evening about taking the fight to this brutal street gang. Let's play the comment and I'll ask you to respond, sir.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Many killers in those gangs, and we're taking them out of our country by the thousands, MS-13.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: So, what about that, and this deadly gang operating in your beloved home state?

EHRLICH: Yes, the president -- what's there to argue with? The president is talking about a deadly gang involved in the drug trade, with lots of bodies around. What's the problem? I don't understand why anyone would defend this gang and their brutal history.

So, the president is usually blunt to the point, whether he's at a rally or a press conference, he tells it like it is. When you have comments like that about this sort of gang, it, sort of, explains part of his popularity. It's blunt, it's real, it's in your face, and it's true, and it's accurate.

EMANUEL: Montgomery County right outside the nation's capital tweeted last Thursday. Montgomery County is committed to building and maintaining a safe and inclusive community for our residents. Understanding tolerance and respect are hallmarks of Montgomery County. Social justice for all is what we strive to achieve in our county. Is that enabling MS-13?

EHRLICH: Well, I don't know if it enables MS-13, but what it is, it's just -- it's nothing. It talks by the issue. And then, of course, they're going to talk about belief -- you're going to ask me about Nazis and Trump and Republicans, and it doesn't -- it's classic. It doesn't get to the issue. It talks by the issue. It's worked for social justice.

Well, what about the rapes? What about the gangs? Why are they there? Because the local government is not helping the federal government do its job. So, they're making a very dangerous environment for women in Montgomery County.

So, yes, what they say is, high-sounding, and sounds good when you say it really fast, but it talks by the issue. When you can't engage, when you lose on the merits, when your precision is wrong, they talk by the issue. It's a classic.

EMANUEL: Acting director Ken Cuccinelli of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, tweeted Friday, Sanctuary County, Montgomery County, Maryland cannot debate the failure of its sanctuary policies on the merits, seven violent assaults, rape, et cetera, including child victims in one month, so they resort to ad hominem attacks using Nazi implications, arguments, out-of-bounds in civil society.

Is he right about that, Governor?

EHRLICH: It's the game plan, Mike. You've seen it, time and time again. When you can't engage on the merits, when your sanctuary city policy -- when your sanctuary policy, generally, is leading to a more dangerous environment at home. What do you do when things go wrong? You talk by the issue. You blame Nazis and Republicans and President Trump.

You do anything other than engage on the issue. That's what Ken is talking about. It's very frustrating. At least, at some point, we need to engage. It's a real dangerous situation we have here, women are being raped. It's a serious issue. You just can't get by it with singing Kumbaya.

EMANUEL: Let's briefly switch subjects. Let's take a look at this headline from the Baltimore Sun yesterday. Trump to attend House Republican retreat in Baltimore on Thursday, less than two months after calling Baltimore a rat and rodent infested mess where no human being would want to live. President Trump will be there this week. Will there be protests?

EHRLICH: Well, you know what, there may be protests, but I love the president engaging. You may know a lot of Republicans from my generation are Jack Kemp fans. Jack Kemp would show up. You know, he would engage in the communities. This president has a real record in the community here.

So, I want him to talk about criminal justice reform and black unemployment numbers and community grants and trying to empower impoverished communities. He has a terrific record. I want to see him show up, but not just talk to Republicans, talk to the community, talk to the Democrats, talk to everybody. He's good at it.

I think, politically, as he said in the last campaign, there's no downside to it. We can't do worse, correct? So, again, as Jack Kemp, Republicans applaud it, engage, dialogue, and you're going to pick up some votes as a functional substance, not just a scare campaign for progressives to engage in a daily basis.

EMANUEL: All right. Former governor of Maryland, Robert Ehrlich, thank you so much for your time, sir.

EHRLICH: Good to see you, my friend.

EMANUEL: Thank you. The Trump administration issuing new visa guidelines tonight for residents fleeing the Bahamas and Florida Republican senators Marco Rubio and Rick Scott are asking the Trump administration to go easy on those asylum-seekers. Here's how President Trump sees it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We have to be very careful. Everybody needs totally proper documentation. I don't want to allow people that weren't supposed to be in the Bahamas, to come into the United States, including some very bad people and some very bad gang members, and some very, very bad drug dealers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: Rescue teams are continuing to recover bodies in Abaco, one of the hardest hit areas of the Bahamas. Correspondent Jeff Paul is riding along with the lead U.S. federal agency coordinating relief efforts.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JEFF PAUL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: From corporations like Delta, flying over supplies, to ordinary folks who are pitching in, the help is coming from all over, including the U.S. government. We got a firsthand look at those very efforts, flying out of the air reserve base and homestead with USAID.

Administrator Mark Green and his team brought us along as we toured some of the hardest hit spots in the Bahamas. Green compared what he saw in places like Abaco, to a bomb going off. And that's why the U.S. is providing $2.8 million in aid.

Once on the ground, they are handing things out like food, water containers, shelter items and hygiene kits. This private airfield now, a makeshift base as the search and rescue efforts continue. This place set up in about 24 hours, likely to double in size.

As you see, personnel from all sorts of different jurisdictions and countries. They tell us the most difficult thing right now is just how vast the landscape is, how desolate it is. The only way they can bring in supplies and will continue to do so, is by air.

Forty-seven metric tons and all, so far, and Administrator Green says, as teams set up their base camps, their work is just beginning.

MARK GREEN, ADMINISTRATOR, USAID: This is American compassion. We always stand with people, particularly our neighbors, when crisis strike. This is who we are as Americans. They know it and we know it.

PAUL: Search and rescue crews tell us they understand the frustrations from those who need help and they are frustrated too that relief can't come faster.

TRACEY REID, PLANS TEAM MANAGER, USA 1: We wish we were there when it happened or directly afterwards, so that we could be there immediately. So, we feel like we're making up for lost time from the moment we hit the ground.

PAUL: Some of the people on the ground say, unlike responding to a disaster on the mainland portion of the U.S., they can't drive in supplies, only further delaying getting those items to those who need it the most. In Homestead, Florida, Jeff Paul, FOX News.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EMANUEL: Texas leads the way in a huge investigation of the search giant, Google. Texas A.G. Ken Paxton is here, next, to explain his case.

EMANUEL: The crackdown on big tech intensifying tonight, nearly every state is joining a bipartisan investigation into Google's market dominance and this is just days after a separate group of states announced an investigation into Facebook. Fox Business Network's Hillary Vaughn is investigating the latest claims. Good evening, Hillary.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Mike, this is not the first anti-trust probe that Google has faced, but it is the largest with attorneys general from all states but California and Alabama joining in. The bipartisan team of state A.G.'s will start by looking into Google's ad practices, how consumer data they collect feeds into their ad dominance resulting in what some watchdogs are calling a monopoly on digital advertising. But some A.G.s say, this investigation could go further.

SEAN REYES, ATTORNEY GENERAL, UTAH: That's what our investigation intends to uncover and reveal, whether Google is delayed by the rules and acted fairly. There's a fine line sometimes between aggressive business practices and illegal ones. Usually the line is very clear, and again, our investigation will determine whether Google has crossed that line.

VAUGHN: Today's announcement was about flexing the power of the attorney general's office to crack down on a company that has had little oversight and tried to force some regulations. Google responding to the investigation writing: "The DOJ has asked us to provide information about these past investigations and we expect state attorneys general will ask similar questions. We have always worked constructively with regulators and we will continue to do so." Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt tells me there is strength in numbers. His state was the first to launch an anti-trust probe into Google, and he says: "Everything is on the table with this multistate investigation."

ERIC SCHMITT, ATTORNEY GENERAL, MISSOURI That's the force and the power of all the attorneys general being there together to get answers and make sure that everybody is held accountable.

VAUGHN: This probe is adding to a pile of problems for Google as they face mounting pressure from Congress, a separate investigation by the Department of Justice, other countries around the world are also investigating the company. Mike.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EMANUEL: Hillary Vaughn, thanks very much. Our next guest is leading the charge against Google and the massive anti-trust probe. Let's bring in Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton. General, great to have you.

KEN PAXTON, ATTORNEY GENERAL, TEXAS: Thanks for having me on. I appreciate it.

EMANUEL: Why is this necessary, sir?

PAXTON: We have had complaints from other companies, from individuals for years and years. It's not -- this is an organic thing. It's not coming up through a particular A.G.'s office. And there've been enough of those complaints that we felt like it was time to take a look at it.

EMANUEL: Washington Post's take on your efforts as this: "For years, Silicon Valley has been relatively free of regulation, particularly in Washington. Former President Barack Obama took a hands-off approach to encourage the industry's growth and Congress never took serious action. But a series of scandals including the misuse of social media during the 2016 election thrust of the industry into the political spotlight, prompting some state and federal policy makers to question whether companies have become too big, too powerful, and too unchecked." Does the Washington Post have this right?

PAXTON: They may have this right. We're looking -- that's exactly what we're looking at. We've got a company here, an online advertising, supposedly everything is free. Everything is free for all of these searches. The reality is, they're making $117 billion a year, which means there's a lot of money being made and they control the buy side, the sell side, the (INAUDIBLE), they control the entire market, and so we're concerned.

EMANUEL: I guess some folks are going to ask what about some of these other big company? The Amazon, the Facebook, do you have your eyes on them as well?

PAXTON: So, I know the Department of Justice is looking at some of those companies. Our focus is primarily on Google and that's where we're going to start.

EMANUEL: What are you concerned you may find?

PAXTON: Look, we are concerned about dominance of one player and how that affects consumers because while they may think that the Internet is free, that the searching is free, it's really not free when they're making $117 billion. And those costs ultimately are passed on to consumers, and so consumers don't really understand, are not aware, that they're actually paying a very high price because there's one player and the one player can charge higher prices.

EMANUEL: Let me play for you something Elizabeth Warren has been saying out on the campaign trail and I'll get you to respond, sir.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We got the big banks. We've got the -- we've got big tech, right? Over and over and over. So, we got a couple of things we can do about this. Part one, how about if we got a president who has the courage to enforce the anti-trust laws that are on the books?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: Your thoughts on what she is saying?

PAXTON: Well, I think we do have a president that's looking at that. We have -- we've talked to William Barr, we've talk to some of the people that work for them. They're definitely interested in the same issues. So, her criticism of the administration is not accurate. They are interested in this -- and as you can see, there are almost every state in the country, this goes across party lines. This is an issue that affects all of us and consumers across the country.

EMANUEL: Attorney General Ken Paxton of the great state of Texas, nice to see you sir

PAXTON: Thank you. Good to see you too.

EMANUEL: Fox News Alert, Democratic Governor Gavin Newsom signing a bill to limit vaccine exemptions in California schools, anti-vaccination protesters blocking several entrances to the state capital tonight and to Newsom's office. California highway patrol confirming there were several arrests.

After calling off the controversial Taliban talks, what's President Trump's next move on Afghanistan? Who better to ask than Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst, General Jack Keane, next.

EMANUEL: Tonight, President Trump says he is through talking peace with the Taliban for now, despite campaigning on bringing our troops home and ending America's longest war. Let's talk about the big picture of the Afghan War with Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst General Jack Keane. General, it's great to have you here.

GEN. JACK KEANE (RET.), FOX NEWS SENIOR STRATEGIC ANALYST: Yes, good to be here, Mike.

EMANUEL: One of the top Republicans in the House: Liz Cheney, is praising President Trump for calling off the talks. Take a listen and I'll ask you to respond.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. LIZ CHENEY (R-WY): I am very glad that the president said these talks are dead, we're not going to be negotiating with them. You can't trust the Taliban. You know, we've been talking to the Taliban for years but the notion that somehow, we think they're going to be a partner for peace, that somehow, they're going to give us counterterrorism assurances.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: Is at the right call, General Keane?

KEANE: Yes, absolutely. Listen, what the Taliban did almost a year ago before the negotiations began, they told their fighters to increase the level of activity and the level of fighting and kill as many as you can to include Americans. and they did that for the single purpose of increasing their leverage at these negotiations. That's the kind of folks that we're dealing with here. So, what do we got now? President made the right call; we got an opportunity to reassess and reset and let's go get us a better deal. This thing was moving, I believe, in the wrong direction.

New deal, (INAUDIBLE) should be -- we don't talk unless a cease-fire, let's stop the killing. That makes sense. Second thing is, we got to get the Afghan government involved, not just us. Third thing, Pakistan, their new leadership, the general in charge, the president in charge said we're backing away from our predecessors -- we want a stable Afghanistan, we're no longer (INAUDIBLE) war. Let's put them to the test about that. The other thing, is we've got to make certain that this is not in a deal.

A timetable withdrawal, because that was going to be announced, that we would get out of there by the end of 2020. We should not have a timetable drive that. We should not make an announcement like that. The conditions should be the driver of that. And I think we got to get the Afghan government to absorb all the Afghan cost and just have the United States pay for U.S. costs. I think we can get that worked out.

EMANUEL: It's worth-noting almost 75 years after the end of World War II, we still have troops in places like Germany and Japan. 66 years or so after the Korean conflict we still have plenty of troops keeping an eye on North Korea. Is there any reason why the United States shouldn't keep some troops in Afghanistan to keep an eye on things and make sure there's not another 9/11?

KEANE: That's a great question people ask me even today. I had an official asking me: what does the end look like? How does this turn out? Well, the fact is, radical Islam is a multigenerational war? We're not close to the end of it. And we're only interested in certain pieces of that war. I would suggest Pakistan, would conduct covert operations in the al-Qaeda there, we got their foot on their neck. Afghanistan is another place -- we keep a modest investment in.

Our viewers may not know that we go into Yemen, Libya and Somalia, attack radical Islamic organizations there, why? Because we believe they have aspirational goals to attack America. Same thing in Syria. Even though we took the caliphate away, ISIS is still there. They have aspirational goals to return to that caliphate and hurt -- to America. So, here, is a half a dozen places where America has national security interests. That requires some level of commitment, Mike, and it's in our national security interests to protect the American people. There are 30 or 40 other places the radical Islamists are involved. We're not getting involved and we don't have the national interest to do so.

EMANUEL: So, if the president were to call you after watching the segment would you say, Mr. President, would just be patient?

KEANE: Yes. Let's get a much better deal, let's hold the Taliban's feet to the fire, and if you're going to continue to kill people, Americans and innocent civilians, the way you are doing wantonly, we're not talking to you. Let's get a cease-fire as the first order of business and then we'll start talking.

EMANUEL: General Jack Keane, I could pick your brain all night, but we're out of time sir.

KEANE: Good talking to you, Mike.

EMANUEL: Thanks for your time.

KEANE: Good seeing you, pal.

EMANUEL: After a late night in Britain's parliament, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson suffering yet another setback. British lawmakers rejecting his request for an election before the country's scheduled departure from the European Union next month. Johnson wanted an early election to help him push through Brexit. The opposition wants to delay Brexit but Johnson tonight is vowing to push ahead with Brexit, though it is unclear how he can do so at this point.

Stick around for a brand-new special series featuring Shannon's interviews with 2020 power partners, the spouses and loved ones of the candidates. She goes inside their loves and lives and finds out who's really in charge in these power couples.

EMANUEL: "2020 IN 60 SECONDS" now, something you don't see in every campaign, a presidential candidate leading a meditation session for her supporters. Spiritual Author Marianne Williamson telling Fox News: meditation may be unique for a presidential campaign, but not for America. She searched for her inner truth in New Hampshire tonight.

Senator Kamala Harris apologizing for her reaction to a remark from a questioner during a Town Hall who called President Trump's actions mentally retarded. Senator Harris laughed. Now, she's apologizing; she says she didn't hear the words and that kind of comment is unacceptable at any rate.

And controversial activist, Linda Sarsour, campaigning for Senator Bernie Sanders, the Women's March co-founder endorsing Sanders' foreign policies and praising him for his stand on Israel. He has proposed leveraging aid to push Israel to change its policies on the Palestinians.

As the campaign trail heats up for 2020 Democrats, tonight we start a new segment where we get to know the better halves behind the candidates. Tonight's first power partner is former Congressman John Delaney's wife April McLain Delaney, whom Shannon met in Georgetown near the power couple's apartment from years ago.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

APRIL MCLAIN-DELANEY, WIFE OF JOHN DELANEY: My husband is actually, if you can believe it, a better cook than me.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Same in my house.

DELANEY: He often says that cooking is one of those things that you can immediately see the benefits of your labor and enjoy them.

BREAM: That's true, that's true.

DELANEY: And so, he -- he's one of these people who has always loved to grill, but he's actually incredible with Italian foods. Also, (INAUDIBLE) is amazing, but he used to cook a lot here and I would clean up --

BREAM: It's a good give and take.

We spoke to April Delaney in one of her favorite spots, dog tag bakery. Near John's old apartment in Georgetown.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: They are made of oats.

DELANEY: Well, it's interesting when I first moved to Washington in 1986, the fall of 86, it was not as broken and divided.

BREAM: The roaring 80s were bursting with optimism and so were the Delaney's.

DELANEY: We started with nothing. I mean, we had nothing when we started. I was working in a law firm; he started his first businesses.

BREAM: While John was launching health care financing start-ups, April forged ahead with her own ambitious legal career.

DELANEY: I practiced for many years as communications attorney and then I went to work for a satellite company.

BREAM: Her next stop, a nonprofit that deals with how all kinds of media affect kids like her four children aged 12 to 23.

DELANEY: Protecting your privacy, skyrocketing anxiety and depression in our nation's youth.

BREAM: Much like her husband, April sounds like a centrist Democrat who appreciates the hard work it takes to get different sides together to find common solutions.

DELANEY: I think in that, you meet a lot of people along the way in Washington and you realize that there's a lot of good to be had. You find it actually processed dormant progress is made one bite of the apple at a time. It's taking government and private sector and consumer groups and nonprofit, and coalescing and taking one step forward in having one bite of the apple.

BREAM: Hearkening back to a different era, one she believes provides lessons for today.

DELANEY: And everyone now wants the whole apple, but actually that's not the way the framers wanted it to be. And actually, hard work and progress come from rolling up your sleeves and really hard work, and that's not encapsulated in a tweet.

BREAM: As we talked to the dog tag, it occurred to me not a lot has changed with the Delaney's since their early days in the kitchen in Georgetown. The stakes are bigger, but it's the old give and take and teamwork. John is vowing to stay in the race despite not making the debate stage in Houston and April is doing her part to help keep them in the 2020 campaign. Like her husband, she believes that getting to the 130,000 unique donors to make the October debate stage is achievable, but more difficult because he's a centrist.

DELANEY: If you really have a fringe, or if you're already a celebrity or if you have a real fringe either left or right type of message, it's quicker, Americans need to have voices on the Democratic stage that really speak to these problems and are more centrist and talk about stopping the noise.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EMANUEL: And that's the first installment of Shannon's new series, "2020 POWER PARTNERS." And don't forget to tune into FOX NEWS @ NIGHT on Thursday evening after the third Democratic primary debate, our Chief Political Anchor Bret Baier will head up our special debate coverage live from Houston, 11:00 p.m. Eastern until 1:00 a.m.

Today the White House presented six Dayton, Ohio, police officers who responded to last month's mass shooting with the nation's highest award for public safety. The six officers confronted the shooter within 30 seconds, a swift response credited with preventing more deaths. The president also honored the bravery of five civilians with heroic commendations for having helped others as a gunman opened fire at a Wal-Mart in El Paso. They heroically stood for others in the darkest moments of despair. They are all our "MIDNIGHT HEROES."

Most-watched, most trusted, and most grateful you spent the evening with us. Good night from Washington. I'm Mike Emanuel. I'll see you tomorrow night.

urn:contentItem:5W9R-PPN1-JCMN-Y15X-00000-00Trump says tech giants like Facebook, Google, and Amazon 'discriminate against' him and colluded with Democrats during his election run2019-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:59ZLexisNexisTrump says tech giants like Facebook, Google, and Amazon 'discriminate against' him and colluded with Democrats during his election runLisa Eadicicco

Jun 10, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin President Donald Trump[1] said on Monday whilespeaking with CNBC[2] that tech companies such as Google, Facebook, and Amazon "discriminate" against him. The comments come after tech firms have faced scrutiny over whether their platforms enforce political bias. Trump also briefly commented on the issue of regulation in the tech industry over antitrust concerns, saying that "obviously, there is something going on in terms of monopoly." Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[3] President Trump said while speaking with CNBC's "Squawk Box"[4] on Monday that tech companies such as Facebook, Google, and Amazon "discriminate against" him.

"People talk about collusion, I can tell you that the real collusion is between the democrats and these companies, because they were so against me during my election run," he said to the network when asked about the ongoing antitrust concerns surrounding these companies. "Everybody said if you don't have them, you can't win. Well I won, and I'll win again." The comments come after executives from Google, Facebook, and Twitter testified before Congress last year to address allegations of bias on their platforms, among other topics. Google CEO Sundar Pichai denied such allegations[5] when appearing before Congress in December, saying that the company's only mission is to provide "accurate, trusted information." Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey said when testifying in September[6] that his company "strongly believes in being impartial" and that it strives "to enforce our rules impartially." Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has also denied such allegations of intentional bias, saying last April that the goal of his company is to "be a platform for all ideas." President Trump later added that "obviously, there is something going on in terms of monopoly," when asked again whether there's an antitrust issue with tech firms with large market sizes, like Facebook and Google. Read more: Trump drops the biggest hint yet that he's coming after the big tech 'monopoly' with potential billion-dollar fines[7] Companies such as Facebook, Google, Apple, and Amazon have come under scrutiny in recent months over their size and the amount of power they hold within their respective industries. Democratic senator and 2020 presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren proposed a plan in March[8] that would subject large tech firms like Facebook, Amazon, and Google to regulation. Under such a plan, certain large tech firms would have to roll back some acquisitions and would be prohibited from competing in the same marketplaces that they operate. That would mean breaking Facebook away from WhatsApp and Instagram, and Amazon away from Whole Foods. The European Union in particular has cracked down on large American tech firms in recent years. In March, the EU fined Google $1.7 billion[9] over its online advertising practices, accusing the search giant of abusing its market dominance. It's also preparing to probe Apple after music streaming app Spotify filed a complaint with the EU over Apple's App Store practices, according to the Financial Times[10]. President Trump also touched on the EU's regulation of tech companies, potentially suggesting that the United States should be enforcing some type of regulation. He didn't provide any details on how or what that would entail, however. "Every week you see [the EU] going after Facebook and Apple and all of these companies, that are, you know, great companies but something is going on," he said. "But I will say the European Union is suing them all the time. We are going to be looking at them differently ... They get all this money. We should be doing that — they're our companies, so they're actually attacking our companies. But we should be doing what they're doing."NOW WATCH: I've used iPhones for nearly a decade and switched to the Samsung Galaxy S10. Now I understand Android loyalty in a way I never understood before.[11]See Also: Trump drops the biggest hint yet that he's coming after the big-tech 'monopoly' with potential billion-dollar fines[12]Here's why it's so hard to switch from Apple to Android[13]Some Googlers are reportedly fearful of speaking out against YouTube's decisions about Steven Crowder's channel because they're urn:contentItem:5W9M-4YG1-DXY7-W0MF-00000-00Trump says tech giants like Facebook, Google, and Amazon 'discriminate against' him and colluded with Democrats during his election run2019-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:59ZLexisNexisTrump says tech giants like Facebook, Google, and Amazon 'discriminate against' him and colluded with Democrats during his election runleadicicco@businessinsider.com (Lisa Eadicicco)

"Obviously, there is something going on in terms of monopoly," Trump said when asked about large tech firms like Facebook and Google.

AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin

President Donald Trump said on Monday while speaking with   CNBC that tech companies such as Google, Facebook, and Amazon "discriminate" against him.

The comments come after tech firms have faced scrutiny over whether their platforms enforce political bias.

Trump also briefly commented on the issue of regulation in the tech industry over antitrust concerns, saying that "obviously, there is something going on in terms of monopoly."

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

President Trump said while speaking with CNBC's "Squawk Box" on Monday that tech companies such as Facebook, Google, and Amazon "discriminate against" him.

"People talk about collusion, I can tell you that the real collusion is between the democrats and these companies, because they were so against me during my election run," he said to the network when asked about the ongoing antitrust concerns surrounding these companies. "Everybody said if you don't have them, you can't win. Well I won, and I'll win again."

The comments come after executives from Google, Facebook, and Twitter testified before Congress last year to address allegations of bias on their platforms, among other topics. Google CEO Sundar Pichai denied such allegations when appearing before Congress in December, saying that the company's only mission is to provide "accurate, trusted information." Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey   said when testifying in September that his company "strongly believes in being impartial" and that it strives "to enforce our rules impartially." Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has also denied such allegations of intentional bias, saying last April that the goal of his company is to "be a platform for all ideas."

President Trump later added that "obviously, there is something going on in terms of monopoly," when asked again whether there's an antitrust issue with tech firms with large market sizes, like Facebook and Google. 

Read more: Trump drops the biggest hint yet that he's coming after the big tech 'monopoly' with potential billion-dollar fines

Companies such as Facebook, Google, Apple, and Amazon have come under scrutiny in recent months over their size and the amount of power they hold within their respective industries. Democratic senator and 2020 presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren proposed a plan in March that would subject large tech firms like Facebook, Amazon, and Google to regulation.

Under such a plan, certain large tech firms would have to roll back some acquisitions and would be prohibited from competing in the same marketplaces that they operate. That would mean breaking Facebook away from WhatsApp and Instagram, and Amazon away from Whole Foods.

The European Union in particular has cracked down on large American tech firms in recent years. In March, the EU fined Google $1.7 billion over its online advertising practices, accusing the search giant of abusing its market dominance. It's also preparing to probe Apple after music streaming app Spotify filed a complaint with the EU over Apple's App Store practices, according to   the Financial Times. 

President Trump also touched on the EU's regulation of tech companies, potentially suggesting that the United States should be enforcing some type of regulation. He didn't provide any details on how or what that would entail, however.

"Every week you see [the EU] going after Facebook and Apple and all of these companies, that are, you know, great companies but something is going on," he said. "But I will say the European Union is suing them all the time. We are going to be looking at them differently ... They get all this money. We should be doing that - they're our companies, so they're actually attacking our companies. But we should be doing what they're doing."

NOW WATCH: Now that Google and Nintendo offer digital video games, GameStop could have the same fate as Blockbuster

urn:contentItem:5WF6-6JN1-DYHJ-31SY-00000-00Trump says US 'should be suing Google and Facebook'2019-06-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:59ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. C,2,999Trump says US 'should be suing Google and Facebook'By Tony RommWashington PostABSTRACT

Trump did not detail the exact basis for any lawsuits, but he raised the idea while at the same time criticizing European regulators for their investigations into US tech companies.

BODY

The president rapped the US technology giants even as he criticized European regulators for looking into the companies.

WASHINGON — President Trump on Wednesday said the US government "should be suing Google and Facebook and all that," then wagered that "perhaps we will," in a new broadside against Silicon Valley at a moment when it already faces heightened antitrust scrutiny in Washington.

Trump did not detail the exact basis for any lawsuits, but he raised the idea while at the same time criticizing European regulators for their investigations into US tech companies. His comments during an interview on Fox Business came weeks after federal regulators at the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission divvied up the scrutiny of Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google — a move that could suggest the government is in the early stages of an investigation into those tech giants.

Trump later swiped at Google, claiming the search and advertising giant is "trying to rig the election." He then claimed that Twitter has made it "very hard" for users to find and follow him. Trump did not provide new evidence for his latest allegation that the companies exhibit bias against conservatives, which Google and Twitter long have vehemently denied.

"You may need legislation in order to create competition," Trump said in response to a question about how his administration might proceed.

Facebook and Google did not immediately respond to requests for comment, nor did the White House. Twitter declined to comment.

Trump's attacks only add to Silicon Valley's mounting political headaches in Washington, where even bitterly divided Democrats and Republicans have sounded similar alarms about the growing size and power of big tech companies.

Antitrust efforts at the DOJ and FTC are supposed to be independent of political influence from the White House. Even Trump's reference to lawsuits could provoke the ire of congressional Democrats, who repeatedly have criticized the president out of concern he has interfered in past competition-related matters, such as AT&T's purchase of Time Warner Cable, a deal that included CNN.

Meanwhile, Trump repeatedly has attacked Facebook, Twitter, and other social-media sites for exhibiting bias against conservatives. In May, the White House took the unprecedented step of releasing a survey in an attempt to collect personal information and stories about people who say they have been unfairly censored online for their political views, a move that drew sharp criticism from open government and free speech advocates.

This time, Trump's comments came in response to a video posted online by Project Veritas, an organization founded by James O'Keefe that targets reporters and people it deems to be left-leaning. The video purported to show Google employees discussing politics in a way that suggested they targeted conservatives. But the clip had been recorded in secret, without the Google executive's permission or knowledge, and she later said that Project Veritas had edited the video in a duplicitous way.

Earlier this year, Trump had pressed Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey about allegations of bias at a private White House meeting. Twitter long has maintained that Trump, who has more than 61 million followers, experiences fluctuations in his follower count because of the company's effort to find and remove spam accounts.

urn:contentItem:60J7-KWG1-DYTH-G4TB-00000-00TRUMP'S BAN ON WECHAT AND TIKTOK LACKS CLARITY AND WILL NOT SOLVE OUR DATA SECURITY PROBLEMS2020-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:59ZLexisNexisTRUMP'S BAN ON WECHAT AND TIKTOK LACKS CLARITY AND WILL NOT SOLVE OUR DATA SECURITY PROBLEMSStates News ServiceWASHINGTON

The following information was released by the Peterson Institute for International Economics:

Martin Chorzempa (PIIE)

President Trump declared on August 6 that the use of the Chinese mobile phone applications TikTok and WeChat on American soil is a national emergency. His executive orders ban Americans from engaging in an as yet undefined set of transactions with the parent companies of these apps. Rumors have been swirling for weeks that the Trump administration would ban the use of these two prominent Chinese apps in the United States, but these new measures could have far more impact, including extending to usage of these apps outside US borders.

Chinese apps and national security

TikTok and WeChat are two of the most successful Chinese apps. WeChat is a "super app" that has become a necessity for daily life in China, combining messaging, social media, news, transport, payments, and more into one powerful application used by well over a billion people. Attempts to gain users abroad, however, have foundered outside the Chinese diaspora. TikTok is a short video app specially designed for the market outside China. It has become the first Chinese app to take off abroad, with hundreds of millions of users all over the world, thanks to a powerful algorithm. In fact, Chinese authorities banned TikTok from the start because it is not subject to the same censorship and other controls as its domestic counterpart Douyin. Blocking apps is par for the course for China, which has long used its "great firewall" and an extensive censorship apparatus to block foreign apps and websiteslike Facebook, Twitter, and Googleand much more.

TikTok expanded into the United States when its owner ByteDance purchased US-based lip-synching app Musical.ly in 2017, which it then merged into TikTok. ByteDance did not clear the purchase with the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS), the US government body that reviews foreign investments for national security threats. With some justification, Bytedance probably thought that acquiring an app mostly used by teenagers to make lip-synch videos was unlikely to be worth reporting. However, even if it would have sailed through a review back then, its lack of reporting left it vulnerable to forced divestment when security concerns grew over its subsequent growthits use spreading even to US military recruitersand revelations about its privacy practices, misinformation, and censorship. The US government has ordered ByteDance to divest TikTok's US business, and Microsoft is now in talks to acquire some of TikTok's businesses.

TikTok's success abroad was bound to run into two major headwinds: a hawkish shift to rethink the US relationship with China, especially with regard to technology and security, and a global awakening of the problems that can come with big tech platforms, such as data privacy, misinformation, and surveillance. These concerns, and probably some protectionism, were behind India's recent move to block a wide variety of Chinese apps. All tech platforms are facing more scrutiny today, but those with Chinese owners pose more complex questions, such as what access the Chinese Communist Party has to sensitive data gathered on foreign users or to what extent it could order apps to extend censorship and misinformation outside its borders. These are thorny questions beyond the scope of this post.1

Trump's executive orders

The executive order issued August 6 sets a 45-day deadline after which "any transaction that is related to WeChat by any person...subject to the jurisdiction of the United States, with Tencent...or any subsidiary" is banned; a second executive order the same day similarly bans ByteDanceand by extension, TikTok. After an initial panic in the online gaming market, where Tencent, the multinational conglomerate that developed WeChat, is one of the world's largest investors, the administration quickly clarified that Tencent investees outside of WeChat are not part of the order. The scope of "transaction" is yet to be defined.

Impact of the executive orders is unclear

Much of the orders' impact and scope remain unclear because they do not cite or appear to fit under pre-existing economic policy tools like export controls and sanctions that have established laws, regulations, definitions, and precedents to provide predictability. Instead, they declare an ad hoc emergency and cite another executive order on securing the information and communications technology supply chain, one that I have criticized as providing overly wide latitude to the executive branch. The orders use language similar to what is used in financial sanctions imposed on regimes like North Korea, banning American companies and citizens from just about any business transactions with the sanctioned entity, and going far beyond the export restrictions placed on entities like the telecommunications giant Huawei that have been put on the "entity list," a blacklist that forbids exports of US goods to entities the United States deems a threat to security or foreign policy.

Both orders will probably force ByteDance and WeChat to be removed from Apple and Google's US app stores, but repercussions are unlikely to end there. Apple and Google's app stores outside the United States might be exempt from action if they are run by non-US subsidiaries, but they would face a serious compliance burden because US citizens would need to be blocked from any "transactions" involving WeChat or Bytedance that fall within the scope of the order. Since the rules as written apply to anyone in the United States and to US citizens or permanent residents everywhere, a Chinese tourist in San Francisco or an American student in Beijing adding money to their WeChat digital wallet could be in legal trouble for violating the order. If the WeChat ban stands, its impact will fall the hardest on those with family in China who rely on WeChat to communicate. Most Western app alternatives are blocked in China, and email and other methods are no substitute for the group chats that have become a staple of life in China.

The executive order on TikTok in a way duplicates a US government order to divest TikTok's US business that ByteDance has already agreed to comply with. The executive order's ban on dealing with ByteDance would seem to complicate rather than facilitate the earlier deal by adding legal risk to the acquiror, which surely will require many transactions with ByteDance into the future to disentangle and settle a multibillion-dollar investment.

Conclusion

Worryingly, the orders signal a US government embrace of a vision for the internet that more resembles Beijing's vision of closed-off cyber sovereignty than the longstanding US tradition of championing an open internet. Any direct security gain from banning Chinese apps must be considered in that context. While the orders are aimed at China today, one of the long-term losers could well end up being US technology companies that today dominate the global market. US bans on foreign apps could provide cover to other countries to spin up their own national security justification to ban what are to them foreign appsfrom US companies like Facebook and Google. This possible scenario has led even Mark Zuckerberg, who heads TikTok's main competitor Facebook, to call such a ban "a really bad long-term precedent."

As Samm Sacks, a cybersecurity policy expert at the think tank New America, has persuasively argued, real and pressing security concerns around data and privacy cannot be solved with ad hoc bans on apps based on their parent company's origin. Right now, it is too easy for anyone, even foreign governments, to buy or hack sensitive data on American citizens without harvesting it directly from apps or by buying up companies. Rather, the US government needs its own robust data protection regime to protect citizens' privacy and national security.

Note

1. CitizenLab has shown that WeChat accounts registered outside of China provide inputs to China's censorship apparatus.
